modelStudio - perks and features

Hubert Baniecki

2019-08-16

Source: vignettes/vignette_modelStudio.Rmd
vignette_modelStudio.Rmd

modelStudio parameters

Let’s use DALEX::HR dataset to explore modelStudio parameters:

train <- DALEX::HR[1:100,]
train$fired <- ifelse(train$status == "fired", 1, 0)
train <- train[,-6]

head(train)
gender age hours evaluation salary fired
male 32.58267 41.88626 3 1 1
female 41.21104 36.34339 2 5 1
male 37.70516 36.81718 3 0 1
female 30.06051 38.96032 3 2 1
male 21.10283 62.15464 5 3 0
male 40.11812 69.53973 2 0 1

Prepare data and model for the explainer:

library("randomForest")
model <- randomForest(fired ~., data = train)

test <- DALEX::HR_test[1:100,]
test$fired <- ifelse(test$status == "fired", 1, 0)
test <- test[,-6]

explainer <- DALEX::explain(model = model,
                            data = test,
                            y = test[,6],
                            verbose = FALSE)

library("dime")

local explanations

You can pass data points to new_observation parameter for local explanations such as Break Down, Shapley Values and Ceteris Paribus Profiles.

new_observations <- test[1:3,]
rownames(new_observations) <- c("John Snow","Arya Stark","Samwell Tarly")
modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = new_observations)

grid size

You can achieve bigger or smaller modelStudio grid with facet_dim parameter.

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], facet_dim = c(1,2))

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], facet_dim = c(3,3))

animations

You can manipulate time parameter to set animation length. Value 0 will make them invisible.

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], time = 1000)

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], time = 0)

more calculations means more time

You can decrease N and B parameters to lower computation time or increase them to get more accurate empirical results.

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], N = 100, B = 10)

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], N = 1000, B = 50)

progress bar

You can hide computation progress bar messages with show_info parameter.

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1:2,], show_info = FALSE)

Parallel Computation

You can speed up modelStudio computation by setting parallel parameter to TRUE. It uses parallelMap package to calculate local explainers faster. It is really useful when using modelStudio with complicated models, vast datasets or simply many observations are beeing processed.

All options can be set outside of function call. More on that here.

options(
  parallelMap.default.mode        = "socket",
  parallelMap.default.cpus        = 4,
  parallelMap.default.show.info   = FALSE
)

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1,], parallel = TRUE)

Plot Options

You can customize some of modelStudio looks by overwriting default options returned by getDefaultOptions().

new_options <- getDefaultOptions()

new_options$show_subtitle <- TRUE
new_options$bd_subtitle <- "Hello World"
new_options$line_size <- 5
new_options$point_size <- 9
new_options$line_color <- "pink"
new_options$point_color <- "purple"
new_options$bd_positive_color <- "yellow"
new_options$bd_negative_color <- "orange"

modelStudio(explainer, new_observation = test[1,],
            options = new_options)

Python scikit-learn Model

You can use DALEXtra::explain_*() functions to explain various models. Bellow basic example of making modelStudio for scikit-learn model using DALEXtra::explain_scikitlearn().

library(DALEXtra)
#TBD

modelStudio should work with any explainer class object. Find more about making those here.
